SENT.plain: We report a 20-year-old woman with sickle cell disease (SCD) who presented with a severe pulsating headache, nausea, and vomiting
Her history was significant for a past thrombotic event during which she had not used anticoagulation therapy as prescribed
Her mental status was mildly confused
On funduscopic examination, papilledema and retinal hemorrhages were found
Results of a computed tomogram were normal
A lumbar puncture demonstrated increased intracranial pressure (60 cm H(2)O)
Magnetic resonance venography demonstrated a right sigmoid sinus thrombosis
Although SCD has been reported as a cause of thrombotic dural venous sinus events, this case increases the knowledge about neurological complications of SCD
The patient was treated with low molecular weight heparin, blood transfusions, acetazolamide, and methylprednisolone, and her symptoms and signs resolved
